Plaque, Scale, Erythema. The patient has a large, black, scaly plaque on their ear, which is erythematous and covered in black scabs. The lesion is likely a result of psoriasis or another chronic inflammatory skin condition. Treatment plan recommendation: Topical corticosteroids, topical calcipotriol, or systemic therapy with methotrexate or biologic agents.

This patient has a small, erythematous papule on the left side of her nose, with central clearing and black dots on the surface. The papule measures approximately 2mm in diameter. No other lesions are present on the face. The patient reports no pruritus or scaling.
Plaque-like eruptions on the lower legs and ankles. Treatment Plan: Topical corticosteroids and antifungal therapy. Please refer to the image in the link for further details.

Papule, Crusting, Yellow, Erythema. The lesion is a yellow, flat-topped papule with erythematous base and yellow crusting on the tip. It is located on the lower lip. Treatment plan recommendation: The patient should be referred to a dermatologist for further evaluation and treatment. Topical corticosteroids and antibiotics may be prescribed to manage the inflammation and infection. The patient should also be advised to avoid any further irritation or trauma to the area.

This appears to be a bulla with pus-filled content, likely due to a bacterial or fungal infection. The center is surrounded by white scale and the surrounding skin appears to be erythematous. The lesion is located on the wrist. Treatment plan recommendation: Topical antibiotic cream and oral antibiotics if the lesion does not improve with topical treatment.

This patient has a nail disorder. The nail appears white and thickened, with a longitudinal ridging pattern. The nail bed appears pink and normal. No further information is provided. Recommendation: A biopsy of the nail should be performed to confirm the diagnosis of onychomycosis. Treatment with an antifungal cream or oral medication may be considered based on the results of the biopsy. The patient should be advised to avoid tight-fitting shoes and to keep the feet dry to prevent recurrence.
